0: This label applies to reviews of food and beverages intended for consumption, including fresh produce, pantry staples, dairy, meats, seafood, baked goods, snacks, spices, oils, vinegars, coffee, tea, and alcoholic beverages. It also covers prepared meals, meal kits, and specialty gourmet items.
1: This label applies to reviews of fresh or frozen meat and poultry products, including beef, pork, lamb, chicken, turkey, duck, and other game meats. Reviews should focus on the quality, freshness, taste, texture, preparation, or packaging of these specific animal protein sources.
2: This label applies to reviews of dried, cured meat products, often seasoned and preserved through a dehydration process. Examples include beef jerky, turkey jerky, pork jerky, and exotic meat jerky, as well as reviews discussing their texture, flavor profiles (sweet, spicy, savory), ingredients, and chewiness.
3: This label encompasses reviews for a wide range of playthings, from board games and puzzles to action figures, dolls, video games, and outdoor recreational equipment. Reviews will discuss aspects like entertainment value, durability, educational benefits, age appropriateness, and the overall play experience.
4: This label applies to reviews of video games, board games, card games, and other forms of interactive entertainment. Reviews should focus on gameplay mechanics, graphics, sound design, story, replayability, and overall enjoyment of the game.
5: This label applies to reviews for physical or digital games where the primary objective is to solve a problem or complete a pattern through logic, deduction, or spatial reasoning. This includes jigsaw puzzles, crosswords, Sudoku, logic puzzles, escape room games, and brain teasers. Reviews should focus on aspects like difficulty, replayability, clarity of instructions, quality of materials (for physical puzzles), or user interface and engagement (for digital puzzles).
6: This label applies to reviews of physical jigsaw puzzles, including those with varying piece counts, themes (e.g., landscapes, art, cartoons), and materials (e.g., cardboard, wood). Reviews should focus on aspects like image quality, piece fit, durability, difficulty, and the overall enjoyment of assembling the puzzle.
7: This label applies to reviews of tabletop games, including strategy games, party games, card games, role-playing games, and cooperative games. Reviews should focus on gameplay mechanics, components, replayability, player interaction, and overall enjoyment of the game experience.
8: This label applies to reviews of any drinkable liquid, including water, juices, sodas, teas, coffees, alcoholic beverages like beer, wine, and spirits, as well as milk and dairy alternatives. Reviews should focus on taste, aroma, ingredients, packaging, and overall drinking experience.
9: This label applies to reviews of liquid beverages intended for consumption, typically made from the extracted liquid of fruits or vegetables. This includes fresh juices, reconstituted juices, and juice blends, as well as smoothies and similar fruit/vegetable-based drinks. Reviews should focus on taste, quality, ingredients, packaging, and overall satisfaction with the beverage itself.
10: This label encompasses reviews for products related to personal grooming, cosmetics, skincare, haircare, and fragrances. It includes items like makeup, lotions, shampoos, conditioners, perfumes, and tools used for beauty application. Reviews will discuss product performance, ingredients, scent, texture, effectiveness, and personal aesthetic outcomes.
11: This label encompasses reviews for cosmetic products applied to the face and body to enhance appearance. This includes items like foundation, concealer, blush, bronzer, highlighter, eyeshadow, eyeliner, mascara, lipstick, lip gloss, and nail polish. Reviews should focus on the product's performance, color payoff, longevity, texture, application, and overall aesthetic results.
12: This label applies to reviews of artificial nails, nail polish, nail care products (like cuticle oil or strengtheners), and nail art supplies. It also includes reviews of services related to nail care, such as manicures and pedicures.
13: This label encompasses products and reviews related to materials, tools, and finished goods for artistic and craft-based activities. This includes items like paints, brushes, canvases, yarn, knitting needles, scrapbooking supplies, clay, sculpting tools, and decorative craft kits. Reviews will focus on the quality, usability, and creative potential of these items, as well as the artistic or crafting outcomes achieved.
14: This label encompasses reviews for art supplies used for drawing and painting. This includes items like pencils, charcoal, pastels, crayons, markers, paints (watercolor, acrylic, oil), brushes, canvases, sketchbooks, drawing pads, easels, and related accessories. Reviews will discuss the quality, performance, color vibrancy, texture, ease of use, and durability of these artistic materials.
15: This label applies to reviews of collectible or play figures that are designed to represent characters from movies, TV shows, video games, or comic books, often with articulated joints for posing and action.
16: This label applies to reviews of collectible figurines, statues, and action figures, often based on popular characters from movies, video games, or anime. Reviews typically discuss the figure's sculpt quality, paint application, articulation (for action figures), accessories, and overall faithfulness to the source material, as well as packaging and display value.
17: This label encompasses reviews for items specifically designed to be used with dolls, such as clothing, furniture, vehicles, and other play accessories. It includes items like dollhouses, strollers, food sets, and hair styling tools intended for doll play.
18: This label applies to reviews of toys designed to resemble human or animal figures, often used for imaginative play. This includes baby dolls, fashion dolls, action figures, stuffed animals, and other collectible figurines.
19: This label applies to reviews for physical card games, including collectible card games (like Magic: The Gathering or Pokémon), trading card games, board games that primarily use cards for gameplay, and party card games. Reviews should focus on the game's mechanics, strategy, replayability, artwork, and overall enjoyment as a card-based gaming experience.
20: This label applies to reviews of electronic drawing tablets, also known as graphics tablets or pen tablets, used for digital art, illustration, and design. These devices typically include a pressure-sensitive stylus and a surface that translates pen strokes into digital input, often used with software like Photoshop, Illustrator, or Clip Studio Paint. Reviews should focus on aspects like pen accuracy, pressure sensitivity, tablet size and portability, build quality, compatibility with operating systems and software, and the overall user experience for artists and designers.
21: This label is for reviews of toys specifically designed for infants and toddlers, typically aged 0-3 years. This includes items like rattles, soft blocks, stacking rings, activity cubes, push walkers, and simple puzzles that are safe and developmentally appropriate for very young children.
22: This label applies to reviews of toys designed to help young children learn to identify and match shapes. Products include classic shape sorters with holes and corresponding blocks, stacking rings, and other educational toys that focus on shape recognition and fine motor skill development. Reviews will likely discuss a child's engagement with the toy, the durability of the pieces, and how well the toy teaches shape concepts.
23: This label encompasses products and reviews related to maintaining personal health and hygiene, including items like skincare, haircare, oral care, vitamins, supplements, and over-the-counter medications. Reviews will discuss the effectiveness, ingredients, application, and overall experience with these health and personal care items.
24: This label applies to reviews for products used for personal hygiene, grooming, and beautification. This includes items like soaps, shampoos, conditioners, lotions, deodorants, makeup, skincare products, oral hygiene items, hair styling products, and shaving supplies. Reviews should focus on the product's effectiveness, scent, texture, ingredients, and overall user experience related to personal care routines.
25: This label encompasses reviews for products designed to reduce or eliminate body odor and/or sweat. This includes antiperspirants, deodorants, body sprays, and roll-on or stick formulations. Reviews may discuss effectiveness in odor control, sweat reduction, scent profiles, skin sensitivity, application methods, and longevity.
26: This label applies to products and reviews focused on improving health and well-being through diet, supplements, or lifestyle choices. This includes vitamins, minerals, herbal remedies, protein powders, meal replacement shakes, probiotics, and discussions about their effectiveness, ingredients, and impact on energy levels, digestion, immunity, or overall health.
27: This label encompasses reviews for edible bars and beverages designed for nutritional supplementation, energy boosts, or meal replacement. This includes protein bars, granola bars, energy bars, meal replacement shakes, protein powders, and electrolyte drinks.
28: This label applies to products and reviews related to educational materials, courses, and learning experiences. This includes textbooks, study guides, online courses, tutoring services, educational apps, and any content designed to impart knowledge or skills. Reviews should focus on the effectiveness of the learning content, the quality of instruction, the accessibility of materials, and the overall educational value.
29: This label applies to reviews for products that create or enhance living spaces for animals, such as birdhouses, insect hotels, reptile enclosures, fish tanks, and pet bedding. It also includes reviews for items that improve the natural environment for wildlife, like bat boxes or hedgehog shelters.
30: This label applies to electronic devices and gadgets specifically designed for children, such as educational tablets, interactive toys, smartwatches for kids, video game consoles marketed to younger audiences, and other tech products intended for entertainment, learning, or communication by children. Reviews should focus on aspects relevant to child use, like safety features, age appropriateness, ease of use for kids, educational content, durability, and parental controls.
31: This label encompasses products used for cleaning, maintaining, and organizing homes, including items like detergents, disinfectants, sponges, paper towels, trash bags, air fresheners, and storage solutions. Reviews for these products will likely discuss their effectiveness in cleaning, scent, durability, value for money, and ease of use in domestic settings.
32: This label applies to reviews of batteries specifically designed for household use, such as AA, AAA, C, D, and 9V batteries used in remote controls, toys, flashlights, and other common household electronics. Reviews should focus on battery performance, longevity, power output, and value for money in these everyday applications.
33: This label applies to toys designed for young children that encourage movement and coordination through pushing or pulling. Examples include toy strollers, wagons, walkers, and pull-along animals or vehicles. Reviews should focus on the toy's durability, ease of assembly, stability for walking, and how well it engages a child's motor skills and imaginative play.
34: This label applies to reviews for soft, cuddly toys filled with stuffing, often resembling animals or fictional characters. These are typically purchased as gifts for children or as decorative items, and reviews often focus on their softness, durability, appearance, and suitability for play or display.
35: This label encompasses reviews for three-wheeled vehicles designed for children, typically used for play and recreation. Products include classic pedal-powered tricycles, ride-on toys with handlebars and pedals, and sometimes larger, more robust models with parental steering or push bars. Reviews will likely discuss durability, ease of assembly, safety features, and how well the tricycle suits a child's age and size.
36: This label applies to reviews for wheeled vehicles designed for personal transport, typically for children or recreational use. This includes kick scooters, electric scooters, pull wagons, and similar ride-on toys or personal mobility devices. Reviews will likely discuss aspects like maneuverability, durability, ease of assembly, battery life (for electric models), and suitability for different age groups or terrains.
37: This label applies to reviews for products made from or primarily featuring clay or dough, such as modeling clay, play-doh, pottery clay, air-dry clay, and related sculpting or crafting kits. Reviews might discuss the texture, pliability, color, drying time, ease of use for children or adults, and the suitability for specific craft projects.
38: This label encompasses products and reviews related to the maintenance, improvement, or restoration of physical and mental well-being. This includes items like medications, supplements, medical devices, diagnostic tools, personal care products with health benefits (e.g., dental hygiene, skincare for specific conditions), and services or information pertaining to health and wellness. Reviews will focus on efficacy, safety, side effects, ease of use, and overall impact on health.
39: This label applies to reviews for products that are specifically designed to help manage or alleviate allergies, such as antihistamines, nasal sprays, air purifiers, hypoallergenic bedding, or allergy testing kits. It also covers reviews discussing personal experiences with allergies and how a product impacted those symptoms.
40: This label is for reviews of items specifically designed for infants and young children, including but not limited to diapers, formula, strollers, car seats, cribs, toys, clothing, and feeding accessories. Reviews should focus on the product's suitability for babies, safety features, ease of use for parents, and overall value for childcare.
41: This label applies to reviews of physical equipment, tools, and accessories used for specific activities or professions. This includes items like camping gear, sporting equipment, tools for construction or repair, photography accessories, and musical instruments. Reviews should focus on the functionality, durability, performance, and usability of the gear itself.
42: This label applies to floor mats and activity centers designed for infants and young babies to lie on, sit up, and play with attached toys, promoting motor skill development and sensory exploration.
43: This label applies to products and reviews concerning devices, creams, gels, or other consumables used for removing unwanted body hair, including razors, epilators, waxing kits, depilatory creams, and laser hair removal devices. Reviews should focus on the effectiveness, ease of use, pain level, skin irritation, and longevity of hair removal results.
44: This label applies to reviews of products designed for topical application to the skin, including cleansers, moisturizers, serums, treatments for acne or aging, sunscreens, and masks. Reviews should focus on the product's effectiveness, ingredients, texture, scent, and impact on skin health or appearance.
45: This label applies to reviews of products specifically designed for application to the face, such as moisturizers, cleansers, serums, masks, makeup primers, foundations, concealers, blushes, bronzers, highlighters, and facial sunscreens. It also includes reviews of tools or devices used for facial skincare or makeup application, like facial brushes, rollers, or applicators.
46: This label applies to reviews of collectible or decorative figurines, statues, or models that depict animals. This includes items like plastic animal toys, ceramic animal sculptures, miniature animal figures for display or gaming, and detailed animal models.
47: This label applies to products and reviews related to menstrual hygiene, feminine hygiene washes, douches, and other personal care items specifically designed for women's reproductive health and cleanliness.
48: This label applies to reviews of audio equipment, musical instruments, and music itself. It covers products like headphones, speakers, amplifiers, turntables, guitars, pianos, and also reviews of albums, songs, and concerts.
49: This label applies to products and reviews concerning items used for cleaning and maintaining the health of the mouth and teeth. This includes toothbrushes, toothpaste, mouthwash, dental floss, interdental brushes, tongue scrapers, and related accessories. Reviews should focus on the effectiveness of cleaning, freshness of breath, gum health, whitening properties, and overall user experience with these oral care products.
50: This label applies to products and reviews for items intended for adult entertainment or leisure, often with a playful or nostalgic element, such as board games, puzzles, collectible figures, model kits, and hobby-related items.
51: This label applies to products and reviews related to costumes, dress-up clothes, and accessories that encourage imaginative play in children. Reviews might discuss the quality of materials for a princess gown, the fit of a superhero cape, or how well a child engages with a doctor's kit or pirate costume.
52: This label applies to products and reviews related to toys and games that encourage imaginative role-playing, such as dress-up costumes, play kitchens, dollhouses, action figures, and toy vehicles, where children or adults engage in make-believe scenarios and act out different characters or situations.
53: This label is for products that are primarily intended as humorous, surprising, or unusual items, often for pranks, parties, or as quirky gifts. Reviews should focus on the entertainment value, the surprise factor, or how well the item functions as a gag or novelty. Examples include fake poop, whoopee cushions, bizarre gadgets, or items with unexpected features designed to amuse.
54: This label applies to reviews for products used for bathing and personal hygiene, including soaps, body washes, lotions, moisturizers, bath bombs, salts, scrubs, and other skincare items applied to the body.
55: This label applies to products specifically designed for cleaning the skin, such as facial cleansers, body washes, bar soaps, and makeup removers. Reviews should focus on the product's effectiveness in removing dirt, oil, makeup, and impurities, as well as its lathering properties, scent, and impact on skin type (e.g., drying, moisturizing, or suitable for sensitive skin).
56: This label is for reviews of toy sets designed for imaginative play, often featuring multiple components that can be assembled or arranged to create a scene or scenario. Examples include dollhouses with furniture and figures, action figure battlegrounds, farm animal sets with barns and fences, or construction vehicle sets with building elements. The reviews should focus on the playability, durability, and imaginative potential of these interconnected toy components.
57: This label encompasses reviews for any type of puzzle, including jigsaw puzzles, logic puzzles, crosswords, Sudoku, brain teasers, and escape room games. Reviews should focus on the puzzle's difficulty, quality of materials, clarity of instructions, entertainment value, and overall satisfaction with the puzzle-solving experience.
58: This label applies to reviews of miniature houses designed for dolls, including their furniture, accessories, and playsets. It covers both pre-fabricated dollhouses and those requiring assembly, as well as reviews focusing on the quality, design, and playability of these items.
59: This label applies to reviews for products specifically designed for lip care, such as lip balms, lip scrubs, lip masks, and lip treatments. Reviews should focus on the product's effectiveness in moisturizing, healing, protecting, or enhancing the lips.
60: This label applies to reviews of items used to perform tasks, repair things, or enhance the functionality of other products. This includes hand tools, power tools, measuring devices, fasteners, cutting implements, and accessories that are designed to be used with or improve the performance of tools.
61: This label encompasses reviews for tools specifically designed for nail care and enhancement. This includes items like nail clippers, files, buffers, cuticle pushers, nail polish removers, nail drills, UV/LED lamps for gel polish, and artificial nail application tools such as tips and glue. Reviews will focus on the effectiveness, durability, ease of use, and results achieved with these specialized nail instruments.
62: This label applies to reviews for products specifically designed for the eye area, including eye creams, serums, masks, patches, and treatments for dark circles, puffiness, wrinkles, and general skin rejuvenation around the eyes. It also covers products for eye makeup removal and eye protection like sunglasses.
63: This label encompasses products designed for organizing, storing, or dividing pills and medications. Reviews will likely discuss features like compartment size, portability, ease of use for splitting pills, durability, and suitability for travel or daily medication management.
64: This label applies to reviews for products specifically designed for hair care, including shampoos, conditioners, hair masks, styling products like gels and mousses, hair dyes, treatments for hair loss or damage, and hair tools such as brushes and dryers. Reviews will discuss the effectiveness of these products on hair health, appearance, texture, and manageability, as well as user experience with application and scent.
65: This label applies to products and reviews concerning items used to style hair, such as gels, mousses, sprays, waxes, pomades, and texturizers. Reviews should focus on the product's ability to hold, shape, add volume, or create specific hairstyles, as well as its texture, scent, and ease of application or removal.
66: This label applies to reviews of toys that incorporate electronic components, such as those with lights, sounds, motors, or interactive features. Examples include remote-controlled cars, electronic learning games, robotic pets, and action figures with sound effects.
67: This label applies to reviews for products designed for the human body, including skincare (lotions, creams, serums), haircare (shampoos, conditioners, styling products), bath and shower products (soaps, body washes, bath bombs), deodorants, and personal hygiene items. Reviews should focus on the product's performance, scent, texture, effectiveness, and impact on skin or hair.
68: This label applies to reviews for spherical toys designed for play, including but not limited to bouncy balls, stress balls, juggling balls, and balls used in games like catch or kickball. Reviews should focus on aspects like durability, bounce, texture, size, and suitability for different age groups or play activities.
69: This label applies to reviews for products specifically designed for or applied to the eyes, such as eyeshadow, eyeliner, mascara, contact lenses, eye drops, eye creams, and false eyelashes. It also covers discussions about eye conditions, vision correction, or any product that directly interacts with or affects the eyes.
70: This label is for reviews of collectible card games, such as Magic: The Gathering, Pokémon TCG, or Yu-Gi-Oh!. Reviews should focus on the gameplay mechanics, card strategies, deck building, set releases, and the overall experience of playing or collecting these games.
71: This label applies to reviews for products specifically designed to treat, protect, or enhance the health and appearance of feet. This includes items like foot creams, lotions, balms, scrubs, masks, callus removers, anti-fungal treatments, blister pads, arch supports, orthotics, foot soaks, and nail care products for feet. Reviews should focus on the effectiveness, scent, texture, and intended use of these foot-specific items.
72: This label applies to reviews for products specifically designed for hand and nail care, such as lotions, creams, cuticle oils, nail polish, removers, files, clippers, and artificial nails. Reviews should focus on the effectiveness, application, scent, durability, or any other aspect related to the care or enhancement of hands and nails.
73: This label applies to reviews for products designed to protect from or enhance the effects of the sun, such as sunscreen, tanning lotions, sunglasses, hats, and beach umbrellas. It also includes reviews about sun exposure itself, like tanning bed experiences or advice on sun safety.
74: This label applies to reviews of items used for medical purposes, including diagnostic tools, therapeutic devices, wound care products, mobility aids, and personal protective equipment for healthcare settings.
75: This label applies to products and reviews concerning items that assist individuals with everyday tasks and enhance their independence and quality of life, particularly for those with physical limitations, age-related challenges, or disabilities. Examples include mobility aids like walkers and wheelchairs, adaptive utensils, dressing aids, personal care items such as grab bars and shower chairs, and assistive devices for communication or home management. Reviews should focus on the product's effectiveness in simplifying daily routines, improving safety, and promoting autonomy.
76: This label encompasses products and reviews related to the care and well-being of infants and young children. This includes items like diapers, formula, baby food, strollers, car seats, cribs, toys designed for babies and toddlers, and clothing for this age group. Reviews will focus on aspects such as safety, effectiveness, ease of use, value for money, and suitability for specific developmental stages of babies and children.
77: This label applies to reviews for products made primarily of paper or plastic, or where paper and plastic are the dominant materials. This includes items like disposable cutlery, plastic storage containers, paper plates, plastic bags, cardboard boxes, and stationery. Reviews should focus on the durability, functionality, and material quality of these paper or plastic components.
78: This label applies to products and reviews concerning items designed to manage or prevent urinary or fecal incontinence. This includes adult diapers, protective underwear, pads, bed pads, skin creams for protection, and related accessories. Reviews will discuss absorbency, comfort, fit, leakage protection, skin irritation, and ease of use for individuals experiencing incontinence.
79: This label applies to reviews of hair cleansing products, including those for daily use, specific hair types (e.g., oily, dry, color-treated), medicated shampoos, and those with specialized ingredients or benefits like volumizing or smoothing.
80: This label applies to reviews for hair conditioners, including rinse-out, leave-in, deep conditioners, and hair masks. Reviews should focus on the product's ability to moisturize, detangle, soften, strengthen, or improve the overall appearance and feel of hair after washing.
81: This label encompasses reviews for portable music players, digital audio players, and karaoke machines. It includes devices primarily used for listening to music, such as MP3 players, iPods, and other personal audio devices, as well as equipment designed for singing along to music, like standalone karaoke machines, portable karaoke speakers, and related accessories.
82: This label applies to reviews for medications, remedies, and devices specifically marketed to alleviate symptoms of coughs and colds, such as sore throats, congestion, runny noses, and hacking. It includes products like cough drops, syrups, nasal sprays, decongestants, and expectorants, as well as reviews discussing their effectiveness, side effects, and suitability for various age groups.
83: This label encompasses products used for bathing and personal hygiene in the bathroom, including soaps, shampoos, conditioners, body washes, bath bombs, bubble baths, loofahs, bath brushes, and related accessories. Reviews should focus on the effectiveness, scent, texture, skin benefits, and overall experience of using these items for cleansing and relaxation in the bath or shower.
84: This label applies to reviews of products specifically designed for testing or diagnostic purposes, such as medical test kits, educational assessment tools, or scientific laboratory equipment. Reviews will focus on the accuracy, reliability, ease of use, and interpretation of results from these testing products.
85: This label applies to reviews of construction toys, such as LEGO sets, building blocks, magnetic tiles, and model kits, where the primary focus is on the act of assembling, creating, and imaginative play with modular components.
86: This label applies to reviews of construction toys and kits, such as LEGO, K'NEX, Mega Bloks, and similar building systems. Reviews should focus on the quality of the bricks, ease of assembly, playability, creativity, and value for money of these interlocking toy sets.
87: This label applies to products and reviews that focus on alleviating stress, anxiety, or tension. This includes items like calming teas, aromatherapy diffusers, meditation apps, relaxation music, weighted blankets, massage tools, and supplements marketed for their stress-reducing properties. Reviews will often describe feelings of peace, tranquility, improved sleep, or a general sense of calm after using the product.
88: This label applies to reviews of products designed for birth control and family planning, including oral contraceptives, intrauterine devices (IUDs), patches, rings, injections, condoms, diaphragms, spermicides, and emergency contraception. Reviews may discuss effectiveness, side effects, ease of use, cost, and personal experiences with these methods.
89: This label applies to reviews of products intended to supplement the diet with vitamins, minerals, herbs, amino acids, or other dietary substances. This includes multivitamins, single-nutrient supplements, protein powders, pre-workout formulas, and herbal remedies. Reviews should focus on the effectiveness, taste, side effects, or overall experience of using these products for health and wellness purposes.
90: This label applies to reviews of products used to change or enhance hair color, including permanent dyes, semi-permanent colors, temporary color sprays, root touch-up products, hair bleaches, and toners. Reviews should focus on the product's performance in terms of color payoff, longevity, ease of application, hair condition after use, and any associated scent or irritation.
91: This label applies to reviews of medications and over-the-counter products specifically designed to alleviate or manage physical pain. This includes analgesics, anti-inflammatories, topical pain creams, and other remedies for conditions like headaches, muscle aches, arthritis, and injuries.
92: This label applies to reviews for cotton swabs, also known as cotton buds or Q-tips. These are small, typically plastic or paper sticks with cotton wool wound around one or both ends, used for cleaning ears, applying makeup, or for various craft and medical purposes. Reviews might discuss absorbency, sturdiness of the stick, the quality and amount of cotton, packaging, or their effectiveness for specific uses.
93: This label applies to reviews of products used to style hair, such as curling irons, straighteners, hair dryers, brushes, combs, rollers, and hair accessories like clips and headbands. Reviews should focus on the effectiveness, ease of use, durability, and any specific styling results achieved with these tools.
94: This label applies to reviews for products used to treat immediate injuries or medical emergencies, such as bandages, antiseptic wipes, pain relievers, splints, and emergency kits. Reviews should focus on the product's effectiveness in addressing cuts, burns, sprains, or other acute medical needs, as well as its ease of use in a stressful situation.
95: This label applies to reviews for products designed to exfoliate, cleanse, and improve the texture of the skin on the body. This includes physical exfoliants like sugar or salt scrubs, chemical exfoliants containing AHAs or BHAs, and other body treatments aimed at skin renewal or conditioning.
96: This label applies to reviews of physical items used for cleaning, such as mops, brooms, dustpans, sponges, scrub brushes, microfiber cloths, vacuum cleaners, and their accessories like replacement heads or filters. It also includes cleaning solutions and detergents specifically designed for use with these tools, but not general household cleaners for surfaces or laundry.
97: This label applies to reviews of puzzles where the pieces are designed to be inserted into corresponding shaped holes or slots, often featuring knobs or pegs for easier manipulation. These are typically aimed at younger children and focus on shape recognition and fine motor skills.
98: This label applies to products and reviews related to managing diabetes, including blood glucose monitors, insulin, diabetic medications, specialized foods, and accessories like lancets and test strips. Reviews will discuss effectiveness, ease of use, side effects, and personal experiences with diabetes management tools and treatments.
99: This label encompasses products and reviews related to magic tricks, illusions, and the accessories used by magicians, such as wands, decks of cards specifically designed for magic, disappearing coins, and other props used for performing magic. Reviews might discuss the quality of the props, the ease of learning the tricks, or the effectiveness of the accessories in creating illusions.
100: This label applies to products specifically purchased or intended as gifts for others, and reviews that focus on the suitability of the item as a present, its presentation, or the recipient's reaction.
101: This label is for reviews of musical albums, encompassing physical formats like CDs and vinyl, as well as digital downloads and streaming releases. Reviews should focus on the music itself, including song selection, production quality, lyrical content, and overall artistic merit, rather than the purchasing experience or delivery.
102: This label applies to reviews for toys designed to be attached to cribs, such as crib mobiles, rattles, or activity gyms that hang over the crib. It also includes accessories that attach to cribs for organizational or decorative purposes, like crib organizers or canopies.
103: This label applies to reviews discussing products that are intended to aid digestion or alleviate symptoms of nausea. This includes items like antacids, probiotics, anti-nausea medications, ginger chews, or any other product marketed for stomach upset, indigestion, heartburn, bloating, or vomiting. Reviews will focus on the product's effectiveness in relieving these specific digestive or nausea-related issues.
104: This label applies to reviews of interactive toys designed to mimic real pets, often featuring electronic components for movement, sound, and responsiveness. Products include robotic dogs, cats, birds, and other creatures that can be fed, played with, or trained, and reviews will discuss their features, durability, and how well they simulate animal companionship.
105: This label applies to products and reviews related to sexual health, intimacy, and pleasure. This includes items like condoms, lubricants, sex toys, adult novelties, and products for sexual enhancement or reproductive health. Reviews will discuss their effectiveness, user experience, safety, and personal satisfaction related to sexual activity.
106: This label applies to reviews of products designed to promote safe sexual practices, such as condoms, dental dams, lubricants, and sexual health testing kits. Reviews should focus on the product's effectiveness, comfort, ease of use, and any perceived benefits or drawbacks related to safe sex.
107: This label applies to reviews of devices used to measure temperature, including medical thermometers (oral, ear, forehead), cooking thermometers (meat, oven, candy), environmental thermometers (room, outdoor), and industrial thermometers. Reviews may discuss accuracy, ease of use, speed of reading, durability, and specific features like Bluetooth connectivity or memory functions.
108: This label applies to toys designed to be stacked on top of each other or nested inside one another, promoting fine motor skills, spatial reasoning, and understanding of size relationships. Examples include stacking rings, nesting cups, block sets with varying sizes, and shape sorters where shapes fit into corresponding openings.
109: This label applies to products specifically designed to remove makeup from the face, eyes, and lips. Reviews should focus on the effectiveness of the product in dissolving and lifting various types of makeup, including foundation, mascara, lipstick, and eyeshadow, as well as its gentleness on the skin, potential for irritation, and ease of use.
110: This label applies to reviews for temporary tattoos, including those for children's parties, Halloween costumes, body art, or promotional events. Reviews might discuss the ease of application, durability, appearance, skin sensitivity, and how well they wash off.
111: This label applies to reviews for products used for outdoor physical activities and recreation, such as sports equipment, camping gear, hiking accessories, and playground items. Reviews should focus on the performance, durability, and suitability of these items for their intended outdoor use.
112: This label applies to reviews for fabric structures designed for children's imaginative play, such as pop-up tents, crawl tunnels, and playhouses, often featuring themes like castles, forts, or vehicles.
113: This label applies to reviews of products that are primarily scientific in nature, such as laboratory equipment, scientific instruments, research chemicals, educational science kits, and academic journals.
